body:
@nworden 
_now that it's getting a little bigger, do either of you have any preferences about package structure?_
I think breaking some of the concepts up into their own packages is a good idea. If you are doing some refactoring to break out the subclasses, then it might affect @natashaj7 and I when we merge our story. Otherwise it should be okay. 

Are you going to create a new pull request with any changes or should we merge this one?
I'd be happy to wait on the package stuff to avoid conflicts. If Natasha's ok with the subclasses and if there's nothing else, I think this is ready to go.
@nworden It is ready for merge if the changes you suggested look to be fixed.

Just a couple minor nits, then I think it's good to go.
- lines 273 and 321 in MainActivity still look a little long
- it looks like the field for the label has moved up 20 pixels. is that deliberate? if you haven't already, it might be worth running the UI by Olly eventually (he really does put a lot of effort into getting the UI just right), but that can be later (I don't want to it to block merging this in, just wanted to mention it)
This is probably because I totally neglected to manage the activity lifecycle. I should be able to fix that tonight (and I'll check MainActivity too, because I suspect it'll have a similar problem).

Will fix the length of those lines in MainActivity.

It was deliberate to move the label field, good point about running these changes by Olly. We had a brief conversation on slack about what a MVP for this feature would be. We will go forward with what was decided there, and open our pull request when we finish. When Olly gets back from vacation we can further refine the UI for this story.
The code looks good to me. Don't forget to add your names to the source files if you want to.

Agreed on both counts.
I'm going to go ahead and merge this in so that I'm not blocking you on deck-related features tomorrow morning, but I'll leave your pull request open in case you wanted to make any further changes on it.
Actually GitHub closed the other pull request automatically. Didn't expect that.
#20 Importing and exporting decks by @nworden
#20 Importing and exporting decks @nworden
#20 Importing and exporting decks @nworden
Quick fix, lock in portrait mode. Does this still need to be open?
Fix for issue #41
Moved these to separate tech task issues in the issue tracker. #55 #54 #53 #52

I just changed the values in the string constants and kept our vocabulary in code the same. I am open to changing the vocabulary in code as well, but it seemed like a lot of replacing for not much added value.

Definitely agree about the vocab in the code. If we ever use the word "export" for anything else in the UI later (dunno what, maybe if we wound up with a feature that exported all your decks or something), we can change the current code to use "share" then, otherwise I don't see any reason to.

This isn't working as _intended_ per se, but it is working as expected. We do this deliberately because some applications we might want to receive intents from know it's really a ZIP and specify that in the intent they send when the user tries to open the file.

Now, I know you've said there ought to be a way to tell Android about our new filetype, and I agree it _ought_ to be possible, but I can't find a way to do it. Here's a StackOverflow link asking basically what we're trying to do:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5744944/how-to-add-custom-mime-type
The non-negative scored answers are:
- forget about mimetype, look at the host (doesn't work for us because the host is irrelevant in our case)
- use an already-registered mimetype (doesn't work for us because Android doesn't know what a TXC is, and Android doesn't seem to have a way to register new mimetypes, at least not that I can find)
- forget about mimetype, use the file extension (doesn't work for us because we don't always get the original filename, such as when it comes from Gmail)
- use whatever string you want as the mimetype, so long as you set it in the sending intent (doesn't work for us because we're not sending intents, we're just receiving them from other applications)

Ideally, we could just use file extension, and I'd been assuming that was possible when I originally came up with the idea for TXCs. But, we can't always do that, because some applications don't put the original filename in the intent, and we'd miss those if we filtered by file extension.

Debugging tip in case you want to see more of what I'm talking about: I got an app called "Intent Intercept" on my phone. It catches any intent (anything you try to open, or just anything you try to do in general that involves an intent) gives you that app as an option, and if you open it it'll show you all the details of that intent.
What about json as the config language, a more developer and web-friendly format (or, what is this, 2003?)
JSON's fine by me. If no one else disagrees I'll update the doc.
+1 to JSON
Putting a link to issue #69
Able to reproduce on Nexus S API Level 10 using x86

It seems this only happens on a VM on my machine. @lynndupree06 tried to build the same VM to replicate the bug and did not see a crash. Would be interested if anyone else can reproduce with these hardware specs?

@nworden I hear what you are saying—and agree Android does not seem to have a way to add a mime-type to the known list. Weird.

Let's leave this open—we may eventually learn a solution, or feel comfortable removing the intent-filters for ZIP and Octet Steam. But it is a low priority
Doc's about JSON now, and has an example per Jeff's request.

Seems JSON can be interpreted as UTF-8, UTF-16 or UTF-32.

Let's simplify by stating the the expectation of a deck.json is UTF-8.

Cool?
@jwishnie cool, updated doc.
